Jesus said that the (books of the) law and the prophets spoke about him. The New Testament provides numerous fulfillments of Old Testament prophecies about a coming Messiah / God / Savior. And, until many centuries after Christ (about 900 - 1,000 A.D.), quite a few distinquished Jewish rabbis believed many Messianic passages, such as Isaiah 53 ("And the Lord laid on him the iniquity of us all") spoke about the coming Messiah. If Jesus is God then he's the same one who gave Moses the Ten Commandments (note "THE  Angel of the Lord" in the Burning Bush passage - where angel in Hebrew can mean "messenger") on Mount Sinai, and clarified the law in the Sermon on the Mount. If Jesus is the Jewish Messiah as is claimed, then OT Judaism (in God's eyes) is a dead religion apart from Christ. This Thread is for a discussion on the issues involved.

 In addition to Isaiah 9:6-7, this is another prophecy which proclaims that God will incarnate as a mortal, which Christ did. Modern Judaism teaches that there is one God, but not a Trinity. They do not base this on their own Scriptures (which they should give more credence to) but on Rabbinic Commentary. It should also be obvious that, according to the Rabbinic quote from the Targum Jonathan above, this scripture speaks of the coming Messiah. Put two and two together and you have a coming Messiah, born of the line of King David, who will be Jehovah God (incarnate). Only Christ fits this bill.
